variables.input:
timeseries avg(sfm.otelcol.process_cpu_seconds), by: { service.name }
| fieldsKeep service.name

timeseries avg(sfm.otelcol.process_cpu_seconds), by: { service.instance.id }, filter: { service.name == $ServiceName }
| fieldsKeep service.instance.id

1.title: Total physical memory (resident set size)
1.query:
timeseries avg(sfm.otelcol.process_memory_rss), filter: { service.name == $ServiceName AND service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| limit 20

8.title: Cumulative bytes allocated for heap objects
8.query:
timeseries avg(sfm.otelcol.process_runtime_total_alloc_bytes), filter: { service.name == $ServiceName AND service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| limit 20

9.title: Bytes of allocated heap objects
9.query:
timeseries avg(sfm.otelcol.process_runtime_heap_alloc_bytes), filter: { service.name == $ServiceName AND service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| limit 20

10.title: Total bytes of memory obtained from the OS
10.query:
timeseries avg(sfm.otelcol.process_runtime_total_sys_memory_bytes), filter: { service.name == $ServiceName AND service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| limit 20

24.title: exporter current queue size

28.content:
## HTTP Client metrics
These are metrics about the requests that the Collector sends.

32.content:
## HTTP Server metrics
These are metrics about the requests that the Collector receives.

36.title: Average response size

37.title: Average request size

39.title: Average request duration
39.query:
timeseries {sum=sum(sfm.otelcol.http.server.duration_sum), count=sum(sfm.otelcol.http.server.duration_count) },
  by: { http.status_code, http.method }, 
  filter: { service.name == $ServiceName and service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| fieldsAdd avg=sum[]/count[]
| fieldsRemove sum, count

42.content:
## Incoming / outgoing telemetry
Counts for incoming and outgoing Spans/Metric data points/Logs. They are split by the component that processes the data.

44.title: incoming spans - by receiver

45.title: outgoing spans - by exporter

46.title: incoming metric data points - by receiver

47.title: outgoing metric data points - by exporter

48.title: incoming log records - by receiver

49.title: outgoing log records - by exporter

50.title: filtered spans - by filter

51.title: filtered metric data points - by filter

52.title: filtered logs - by filter

53.content:
### RPC metrics
These are similar to the metrics about HTTP requests above, but for RPC-based connections.

54.title: batch size in bytes

55.title: batch size (in "units", presumably one of spans, metric data points, logs)

56.content:
### Batch metrics
These are metrics reported by the [batchprocessor](https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-collector/blob/main/processor/batchprocessor/README.md), if used. They can be used to understand batching behavior.

60.title: RPC request size

61.title: RPC response size

63.title: RPC requests per RPC

64.title: RPC responses per RPC

65.title: RPC client duration

71.title: exporter queue capacity

73.title: Latest data from collector received at
73.query:
timeseries {count=count(sfm.otelcol.process_uptime), intervalStart=start()}, 
  by: { service.name, service.instance.id }, 
  from:-24h, 
  to:now(), 
  interval:1m, 
  filter:{ service.name==$ServiceName and service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| fieldsAdd countIsNull=isNull(count[])                                              // find which buckets have values. null means no value has been recorded into that bucket.
| fieldsAdd lastNonNullIdx = arrayLastIndexOf(countIsNull, false)                    // find the index of the last bucket that is not null, meaning the last bucket that has a value
| fieldsAdd timesAndIndex=record(index=iIndex(), startTime=intervalStart[])       // create a record that contains the interval start times and and index
| expand timesAndIndex                                                            // expand the records to be able to filter
| filter timesAndIndex[index]==lastNonNullIdx                                     // keep only the interval start time for the last bucket that has a value
| fieldsAdd startTimestamp=timesAndIndex[startTime]
| fieldsAdd latestDataArrivedAt=formatTimestamp(startTimestamp, format:"YYYY/MM/dd HH:mm"), latestDataArrivedBefore=now()-startTimestamp
| fieldsKeep latestDataArrivedAt, latestDataArrivedBefore

74.content:
## How to use this dashboard

1. Select a Service Name. You can use the two graphs above or [the aggregated overview dashboard](https://github.com/Dynatrace/dynatrace-otel-collector/blob/main/docs/collector_selfmon_kubernetes_all.json) to find a collector that you are interested in.
2. Select a Collector pod name. You can only ever select one collector instance at a time. If you change the ServiceName, you will have to pick a new collector instance that has that service name. The pod names for a particular Service name will be loaded when you click the ServiceInstanceId selector. You can use the two graphs above to find a collector that you are interested in, or use the K8s pod name if you know it from some other source.

75.title: Total physical memory (resident set size)
75.query:
timeseries sum(sfm.otelcol.process_memory_rss), by: { service.name, service.instance.id }
| limit 20

76.title: Total CPU user and system time in seconds
76.query:
timeseries sum(sfm.otelcol.process_cpu_seconds), by: { service.name, service.instance.id }
| limit 20

79.title: Request count

80.title: Average request size

81.title: Average response size

82.title: Average request duration
82.query:
timeseries {sum=sum(sfm.otelcol.http.client.duration_sum), count=sum(sfm.otelcol.http.client.duration_count) },
  by: { http.status_code, http.method }, 
  filter: { service.name == $ServiceName and service.instance.id == $ServiceInstanceId }
| fieldsAdd avg=sum[]/count[]
| fieldsRemove sum, count

83.title: Request count
